issues.text: whether by the application of the principle of unity and indivisibility of a mortgage decree a non-agriculturist can indirectly get relief which he cannot directly get under the Madras Agriculturists Relief Act

issues.text: whether the executing court sitting under section 47 and Order XXI rule 2 CPC can go beyond the terms of the decree under the guise of interpretation

anchor.surface_text: sitting only as an executing court and their duty was to give effect to the terms of the decree that was already passed and beyond which they could not go. It is true that they were to interpret the decree, but under the guise of interpretation they could not make a new decree for the parties.

issues.text: whether there is anything wrong in law in scaling down a mortgage decree in favour of agriculturist judgment-debtors while keeping the decree intact as regards non-agriculturist co-debtors

anchor.surface_text: There is, therefore, nothing wrong in law in scaling down a mortgage decree in favour of one of the judgment debtors, while as regards others the decree is kept intact. The Madras High Court expressly adopted this view in Rainier v. Srinivasiah

issues.text: whether full satisfaction of the decree should be recorded under section 47 and Order XXI rule 2 CPC exonerating the mortgaged properties and defendant No. 1 from further liability based on payments wiping off the scaled down amount due from defendants 2 to 7

anchor.surface_text: praying that as the amount thus deposited together with the payments already made completely wiped off the amount due under the decree as scaled down by the High Court in favour of defendants 2 to 7, full satisfaction of the decree might be recorded exonerating the mortgaged properties and also the defendant No. 1 himself from any further liability in respect of the decretal debt.

arguments.claim: Full satisfaction of the decree should be recorded under section 47 and Order XXI rule 2 CPC, exonerating all mortgaged properties and defendant No. 1 from further liability, as deposits and payments by defendants 2 to 7 wiped off the scaled down amount due from them

arguments.claim: Mortgage debt is one and indivisible; decree-holders bound to release entire mortgaged property on payment of scaled down amount by defendants 2 to 7, allowing defendant No. 1 indirect benefit of scaling despite rejection of his direct claim

arguments.claim: Executing court under s.47 and O. XXI r.2 must interpret but cannot remake decree or go beyond its terms

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges appear to have overlooked the fact that they were sitting only as an executing court and their duty was to give effect to the terms of the decree that was already passed and beyond which they could not go. It is true that they were to interpret the decree, but under the guise of interpretation they could not make a new decree for the parties.

arguments.claim: Decree directs separate payments: Rs.49,255 + interest by defendants 2-7 for their redemption; full Rs.1,05,000 + by defendant No.1 for full redemption; payment by 2-7 does not exonerate defendant No.1's liability

anchor.surface_text: As said above, the mortgage decree was scaled down by the High Court in favour of defendants 2 to 7 only and the amended decree directs that the said defendants do pay into court the sum of Rs. 49,255 with certain interest and costs on payment of which the plaintiff was to bring into court all the documents...

arguments.claim: Defendant No.1 not violating decree clause; satisfaction of decree against defendants 2-7 frees entire mortgaged property by force of decree; any benefit to defendant No.1 merely incidental

anchor.surface_text: What is said, however, on behalf of the respondent is that he is not claiming any benefit in violation of this clause. By virtue of the decree against defendants 2 to 7 being satisfied, the entire mortgaged property would, by force of the very decree, be freed from the debt and if the respondent gets any benefit thereby, such benefit would be merely incidental or consequential in its nature.

arguments.court_reasoning: Contrary to decree's express terms requiring defendant No.1's full payment for redemption; ignores special nature of MARA

arguments.claim: Madras Agriculturists Relief Act s.7 scales down debts of agriculturists notwithstanding any other law; nothing wrong in scaling decree for agriculturist debtors (2-7) while keeping intact for non-agriculturist (No.1)

anchor.surface_text: section 7 of the Act expressly provides that notwithstanding any law, custom, contract or decree of court to the contrary, all debts payable by an agriculturist at the commencement of this Act shall be scaled down in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.

arguments.claim: Scaling down mortgage decree permissible for some judgment-debtors (agriculturists) but not others, per Rainier v. Srinivasiah

anchor.surface_text: There is, therefore, nothing wrong in law in scaling down a mortgage decree in favour of one of the judgment debtors, while as regards others the decree is kept intact. The Madras High Court expressly adopted this view in Rainier v. Srinivasiah

arguments.claim: Section 14 MARA contemplates separation of debts in joint families where some members are agriculturists, supporting splitting of liabilities

anchor.surface_text: section 14 of the Madras Agriculturists Relief Act which provides for separation of a debt incurred by a Hindu family, some members of which are agriculturists while others are not, affords a clear indication that the splitting up of a debt in such circumstances is quite in accordance with the scheme of the Act.

arguments.claim: Cases like Arunachalam Pillai, Pachigola v. Karatam, Subramanian v. Ramachandra (purchaser getting indirect scaling benefit) inapplicable here as no purchaser involved; judgment-debtors are original mortgagors with distinct statuses under MARA

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the High Courts approach to the case has not been a proper one and the conclusion it has reached cannot be supported in law. The learned Judges appear to have overlooked the fact that they were sitting only as an executing

holdings.reasoning_summary: Executing court must enforce decree terms without remaking or varying under guise of interpretation

holdings.text: Executing court sitting under section 47 and Order XXI rule 2 cannot go beyond decree terms or make new decree under guise of interpretation

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges appear to have overlooked the fact that they were sitting only as an executing court and their duty was to give effect to the terms of the decree that was already passed and beyond which they could not go. It is true that they were to interpret the decree, but under the guise of interpretation they could not make a new decree for the parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limited role of executing court to implement existing decree without alteration

holdings.text: Section 7 MARA scales down debts of agriculturists notwithstanding any other law

anchor.surface_text: section 7 of the Act expressly provides that notwithstanding any law, custom, contract or decree of court to the contrary, all debts payable by an agriculturist at the commencement of this Act shall be scaled down in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual provision overrides general mortgage indivisibility for qualifying debtors

holdings.reasoning_summary: Advisory on ideal decree drafting but enforces as is

anchor.surface_text: Rainier v. Srinivasiah  1 , which is one of the  1  1940 2 M. 39 decisions referred to in the judgment appealed from. The fact that in that case it was a puisne mortgagee and number a mortgagor whose application for relief under section 19 of the Madras Agriculturists Relief Act was allowed, does number make any difference in principle. The puisne mortgagee was made a party defendant in the suit instituted by the first mortgagee to recover his dues and as the puisne mortgagee was liable to pay the debt due to the first mortgagee, he was held to be a debtor and hence entitled to claim the benefit of section 19 of the Agriculturists Relief Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: Scaling down of mortgage decree in favour of agriculturist judgment-debtors while keeping the decree intact as regards non-agriculturist debtors is permissible under the Madras Agriculturists Relief Act.

anchor.surface_text: Arunachalam Pillai Seetharam 1 , where the purchase of the equity of redemp- tion was at an execution sale-- When the 12th respondent purchased the properties in companyrt auction, he took them subject to the burden of the appellants mortgage and if the burden is by reason of the provisions of s. 8 refer.red to above reduced without pay- ment, the purchase proves to that  1  1941 1 M.L.J. 561 extent an advantageous one, and there is numberhing in the Act to deprive him of the fruits of his. lucky purchase, even though he is number an agriculturist.

precedents.cited_proposition: A non-agriculturist purchaser at court auction of equity of redemption takes the property subject to the reduced mortgage burden under the Act granted to the original agriculturist mortgagor.
precedents.cited_holding: When the 12th respondent purchased the properties in court auction, he took them subject to the burden of the appellants mortgage and if the burden is by reason of the provisions of s. 8 referred to above reduced without payment, the purchase proves to that extent an advantageous one...

precedents.cited_proposition: Non-agriculturist purchaser by private sale of portion of equity of redemption entitled to benefit of scaled down debt because he refunds purchase money to vendor.
In execution proceedings, non-agriculturist purchaser of equity of redemption entitled to benefit of scaled down decree in favour of mortgagors even if purchaser's own application refused.
